title: Building a Personal Website Using R
description:
This workshop invites R users with basic/intermediate knowledge who are interested in learning how to build their personal website using the blogdown package (No prior knowledge with blogdown is required).

This workshop will be an interactive presentation, where we will build a website together (like Jenny's site here https://jennysloane.netlify.app/ from scratch. We will also provide further resources that will allow you to continue enhancing your website on your own.

To prepare for this workshop please make sure that you have R and RStudio installed on your computer. It would be great if you could create a Github account if you do not have one already.

Please bring your laptop with you!

NOTE: We are back to running workshops IN PERSON- YAY! Thank you to Nous for their generous support. The COVID-safe room limit is 20 attendees so please only RSVP if you are sure you can come.

BIOS

Tehilla is a Ph.D. student studying cognitive science at UNSW, Sydney. She received her Bachelor and Masters of Science degrees from the University of Basel, Switzerland. Her research focuses on the interaction between risky decision-making and information-seeking behaviour.

Jenny is also a PhD student studying cognitive psychology at UNSW. She received her BA in psychology from the University of Maryland and her Masters of Science in experimental psychology from Syracuse University. Jenny’s research interests include studying the effects of interruptions and time-pressure on decision-making.

title: Tidy Text Analysis: Word frequencies & n-grams
description:
Text is one of the most prominent and extensive data sources in the digital world. It can be an insight into consumer opinions, social media trends, and literary story arches. However, it can be difficult to analyze without specialized tools and commands. The tidytext package and framework makes it easy to go from full text files to clean data and ultimately, analysis!

The workshop will start with the building blocks of text analysis: separating a text into smaller chunks, removing punctuation, and identifying frequent words or phrases. If you’ve joined our previous text analysis meetups before, this will be a great recap; if you haven’t, this will bring you right up to speed! We’ll show you all you need to know so beginners to the topic are very much welcome.

The focus for the evening will be on going beyond individual words in isolation to n-grams: units of a set number of words (e.g. bigrams like “I think”, “think that”, “that tidytext”, “tidytext is”, “is great”.). This will allow us to get a sense of context about words based on the company they keep and address typical text analysis problems (e.g. "happy" preceded by "not" being given a positive sentiment score).

We’ll top it all off with some truly unique visualizations that show the relationship between words, like bigram network plots with ggraph. Materials will be based on the book Tidy Text Mining by Julia Silge and David Robinson (chapter 4).

title: A Little JS Goes a Long Way
description:
We are super excited to collaborate again with R-Ladies Tunis to host a new workshop, "A Little JS Goes a Long Way". The Amazing Maya Gans will give an overview of how javascript is used in R with a brief intro to Shiny app.

Thinking of looking at Shiny under the hood? Through using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript this talk will go through helpful use cases to empower you to start customising Shiny. Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive web apps straight from R. You can host standalone apps on a webpage or embed them in R Markdown documents or build dashboards. It's very easy to write and it is not surprising to see Shiny apps popping up in all manner of applications including healthcare and medical applications.

WHO is this for?
- If you never worked with Shiny and want to understand how it is used?
- If you love Shiny app and want to understand more about how it's customised.
- Both beginners and experienced R users are welcome to join!

AGENDA
7:30–7:35 pm Who we are | Announcement about useR Conference 2021
7:35–8:25 pm A Little JS Goes a Long Way
8:25–8:30 pm Any Qs?

Our speaker, Maya Gans is an experienced R and JavaScript developer, who recently started applying those skills to the clinical trial space. After graduating with her Masters in Botany from the University of Wyoming, Maya interned at RStudio where she created a blocks based programming language called tidyblocks, as well as co-authoring “JavaScript for Data Science”. Currently, Maya writes R packages and Shiny applications to create dynamic, custom data visualisation and exploratory tools to aid in understanding complex data. Maya is also passionate about data science education and has given many talks and workshops about using and creating tools in R.

You can find out more about Maya Gans here:
Twitter: https://twitter.com/mayacelium
Website:https://maya.rbind.io/

Place: Zoom- https://zoom.us/download - The event will not be recorded.
We will send you the Zoom link & the passcode via email a few hours before the meetup. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact us :

#Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-dammam/

title: Empezando con clusterización
description:
En esta sesión comenzaremos a explorar cómo de potentes son los métodos de clusterización para solucionar múltiples problemas y lo haremos a través de varios ejemplos.

Lo aprenderemos de la mano de Elena Rivas Ruzafa (https://www.linkedin.com/in/elena-rivas-ruzafa/) , Head of Engineering - Digital Products que durante la sesión nos guiará y aprenderemos mediante ejemplos.

Dentro del machine learning, la clusterización se enmarca dentro del aprendizaje no supervisado, es decir, esos algoritmos para los que solo disponemos de un conjunto de datos de entrada que no están etiquetados y sobre los que obtendremos información sin conocer de antemano cuál será la respuesta correcta. Esta situación se da muy a menudo y provocará que la forma en la que hemos de testear los resultados sea muy particular. También veremos que la creación de visualizaciones de datos y la generación de gráficos, se convertirá en una parte esencial de la exploración de dichos resultados.

Lo que obtendremos tras el proceso de clusterizacióon será una segmentación de los datos en grupos similares que serán lo que conocemos como “clústeres”. Aunque es un problema de clasificación no debemos confundir clusterización con clasificación. Ambos son métodos de identificación de patrones, pero mientras el primero pertenece al aprendizaje no supervisado, el segundo, más conocido, pertenece al aprendizaje supervisado. También trataremos de explicar estas diferencias.

Además de resolver algunos casos prácticos durante la sesión, veremos cómo estos métodos pueden solucionar diferentes problemas en múltiples ámbitos (en medicina para el diagnóstico de enfermedades, en redes sociales para encontrar grupos de comportamiento similares, en finanzas para generar estrategias dirigidas a los diferentes grupos de clientes...)

Todo esto lo haremos en el entorno de programación R en el que existen múltiples paquetes que implementan algoritmos de clustering y funciones para visualizar sus resultados. Durante la sesión trabajaremos con algunos de los más interesantes.

Estas son las librerías que usaremos, para que vayáis instalándolas. Las dos últimas son las específicas de clustering:

library(tidyverse)
library(gridExtra)
library(dplyr)
library(reshape2)
library(ggmap)
library(factoextra) # clustering algorithms & visualization
library(cluster) # clustering algorithms

Aquí están los materiales! https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_madrid/blob/master/README.md#2021-06-17---taller-online

title: I♥R
description:
Dear R Ladies Aarhus

We are excited to announce our first-ever meet-up. We are happy to welcome all who use R as part of their work routine or as a hobby and are passionate about the R community.

The theme of our first meet-up is I♥R. Our speakers and R enthusiasts will share how R became part of their professional lives and forever changed it. Join us to appreciate how R is more than just software, connect with like-minded people, and expand your network. Stay with us for fun and learning.

We would love to hear from you during the event! What R Ladies Aarhus should be like? Do you crave local professional events for R users? Are you interested in networking or learning R tricks? Do you prefer in-person or Zoom meetings in the future or a combination of both?

This event will take place in Zoom and will be later followed by a separate in-person event where we can safely meet following the current Danish corona guidelines. Stay tuned for an announcement!

Our speakers:

About Amanda:

Bio
Amanda Tilot is a data scientist at Seriously Digital Entertainment and member of RLadies Los Angeles. She previously studied human genetics as a postdoc at the Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics in Nijmegen, and got her start with R as a PhD student. She lives in Los Angeles with her husband and two kids.

I♥R Talk: “Making moves with R”
Since I first installed R in 2013, the language and its community have been a big part of my career path and successes. From using RNA sequencing packages to improve a paper in grad school, to building an online portfolio as a postdoc, to finding community in a new city - using R made life easier and more fun. I’ll share my journey from molecular neuroscience to data science and how R fit into all the big moves in between.

Twitter: @aktilot

About Elena:

Elena is a PhD student in Aarhus University. She holds MD degree from Russians and MSc in bioscience from the Netherlands. She does research in drug utilization and safety and in reproductive epidemiology and women’s health. She is passionate about R, clean and accessible visualizations and causal inference.

I♥R Talk: “Finding my R”
I started using R during my Masters' studies. There was no formal course in R offered by the university and so I started my self-teaching journey. There were many downs, and some more downs before R and I became friends. This journey is continuing and I’m excited to learn new packages and tricks every single day. I’ll talk about my journey from being a beginner to finding my way of analyzing complex Danish data and starting a blog.

Twitter: @evpatora

#IheartR

title: R-Ladies Lightning Talks: How You Use R
description:
Join us in June for an evening of short and insightful talks related to using R. Topics will highlight the breadth of use cases our members solve using R and the packages they love. Stay tuned as we update the list of topics and speakers!

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:10 - Join online
6:10 - 6:20 - Welcome and announcement
6:20 - 7:20 - Talk part 1
7:20 - 7:25 - Short break
7:25 - 8:00 - Talk part 2

Speakers and talk titles:

* Shannon Pileggi - Leveraging the R community for the job interview

Shannon Pileggi (@PipingHotData) is an enthusiastic statistical collaborator and educator with experience partnering on data analysis in corporate, tech, and government settings. Shannon is currently a Senior Statistician at Adelphi Research in Doylestown, PA working in pharmaceutical market research. Shannon’s day-to-day in R include: fine-tuning ggplots to convey analysis results, contributing to an internal package to automate routine analyses/tasks, streamlining work-flows for repetitive analyses, and developing shiny aps.

* Alice Walsh - Data nightmares: True stories for scary data

Alice Walsh (@sciencealice), Ph.D. is a computational biologist who studies diseases at the molecular level. She is also an organizer of R-Ladies Philly and enjoys data cleaning, generating hypotheses from complex data, and mentoring others.

* Zhenya Cherkas - Rshiny : connecting the silos

Zhenya Cherkas is an Associate Director at Johnson & Johnson Global Medical Safety. Using R for over 15 years, she always worked on the better access and use of multiple disconnected data sources for better data science in less time. She holds PhD in Statistics, MS and BS in Mathematics and BS in Applied Mathematics and Computer Science.

* Jake Riley - Headliner: a new package for dynamic insights

Jake Riley is a data analyst at CHOP and the author of several R packages to improve the workflow of data analysis. His new R package, [headliner], allows users to generate dynamic, informative titles for charts and reports. Read more here https://rjake.github.io/headliner/"

* June Choe - Using icon fonts for data viz

June Choe (@yjunechoe) is a PhD student in Linguistics at the University of Pennsylvania, where he studies the mechanisms of human language acquisition and processing. He enjoys blogging about R and reading about data visualization in his free time.

* Madhavi Ratnagiri - Identification of pulmonary dysfunction using machine learning

Madhavi Ratnagiri is a research associate at the University of Delaware, with a PhD in Electrical Engineering and a Masters in Biomedical Engineering. Over the years she has worked with various types of data including speech, image and time sequence. She programs in C++, matlab, perl, R and most recently python.

title: Introduction to using Docker for reproducibility in R
description:
*What are we going to learn:
Docker is a platform for creating “containers” on your system. You can think of them like a mini system on your computer. They are completely self-contained, isolated environments on your system. These containers include their own operating system, application software, scripts, data, etc. Containers are useful for a lot of things, but here I’ll focus on a quick introduction to using Docker for reproducibility in R. I will demonstrate on how to set-up Docker, run R on a Docker container and few other use cases.

*Who is going to present:
Malindrie is a PhD candidate at the Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology, The University of Queensland. She works on developing bioinformatics methods for the analysis of large-scale single-cell data using advanced statistical modelling and uses modern statistics tools to understand human disease. Malindrie completed her Bachelor of Science (Honours) degree in Statistics in 2016.

* When are we meeting?
The talk will start at 5:00 pm for approximately 45 mins and 15 min Q&A. After that we invite you to stay for in-person and/or virtual catch up.

************The presentation will start at 5:00 pm********************
* Where are we meeting?
We will meet at study room 01-W227, Law Library (Walter Harrison Library), UQ St. Lucia campus- this will be a hybrid event with a Zoom link available.

title: First Steps in Spatial Data visualization w/ R-Ladies Chicago
description:
The tutorial is designed for R users from a variety of fields who are interested in working with spatial data and creating maps with R.

No knowledge of cartography is required.

Prior knowledge of (non-spatial) graphic making and data handling with the {tidyverse} in R is recommended.

Speaker Bio:

Dorris Scott is the GIS Librarian and Social Science Data Curator at Washington University – St. Louis, where she provides consultation on projects that use geospatial data along with providing training in various GIS software, programming applications of geospatial data, and data management. She also serves as a liaison between Washington University Libraries and social science departments assisting faculty with their data needs such as data management and data curation. Dorris received her PhD in Geography from the University of Georgia, with a specialization in GIS applications for public health.

title: Beginner friendly introduction to build an R package
description:
What is the first thing that you do when you open RStudio to run your project? You would normally load the relevant R packages. Have you ever thought about the benefits of R packages and how they make our lives easier, removing the need to code complex formula and functions?

If you're interested in R packages, if you've considered creating one but don't know how start, then this is the seminar for you! This month R-Ladies Melbourne is excited to introduce one of our newest committee members and this months presenter, Bocong Zhao!

Bocong is a recent graduate in Commerce from Monash University. She is passionate about R, and is thrilled to share her knowledge and experiences.

In her seminar, Bocong will introduce you to the in and outs of R packages. She will cover their different components including help pages, why they are required, and completion requirements. She will also discuss common errors and how to solve them, and what final checks are needed before uploading to CRAN.

This will be an online event, please connect promptly at 5:30pm.

We hope you can join us in welcoming Bocong, we look forward to seeing everyone there!

R-Ladies Melbourne

title: Working with Databases in R
description:
In collaboration with #NairobiR, we are delighted to welcome you to our next joint virtual meetup on 12th June as the invited trainer Christopher Maronga takes us through Working with Databases in R!

📆 June 12th, 2021 11 AM- 1 PM (EAT)

To sign up ➡️https://bit.ly/databasesinR

About the Trainer, ➡️ Christopher Maronga is a Data Manager (Clinical) at KEMRI-Wellcome Trust. He has over 6 years of experience in health research data management and analysis mostly working using R, SQL and REDCap. Leveraging R’s API capability to seamlessly extract data from data repositories such as RDBMs and web-based databases such as REDCap has made data use very easy and efficient across industries.

In this talk, Maronga will share with us practically gained experience in accessing these databases, and how you can turn your R into a powerful tool for accessing MySQL database and writing SQL code to pull and query your data from within the R environment.
We will share the zoom link and event details with the registered participants.

All are welcome!

Looking forward to e-seeing y'all.

For any inquiries or comments, contact us on;

Email address: nairobi@rladies.org

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/r-ladies-nairobi-2572841b3/

Twitter: @RLadiesNairobi

title: R4Bioinfo Workshop: Introduction to Ensembl REST API - PART2
description:
We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a series of two workshops about Introduction to Ensembl REST API. This meeetup will cover the second part.

Date/Time: Friday, June 11th, 2021 from 6 PM to 8:15 PM (GMT+1)
Place: ZOOM

▶️ Invited trainer: Dr. Aleena Mushtaq and Dr. Michal Szpak

▶️ About Dr. Aleena Mushtaq:
(https://www.linkedin.com/in/aleena-mushtaq-417bb6133/)
Aleena’s background is in Biomedical and Molecular sciences. She completed her PhD in 2020 at the University of East Anglia, UK. For her doctorate she studied the dynamic relationship of host and microbiota in the gut-liver axis in response to Western diets. She joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2021 and delivers training on Ensembl resources.

▶️ About Dr. Michal Szpak:
(https://www.linkedin.com/in/michal-szpak/)
Michal took a degree in biology at the University of Warsaw, where he
studied ancient DNA. He subsequently moved to bioinformatics and
explored human genetic variation across different ethnicities in his
master’s degree research at the Center for Public Health Genomics,
university of Virginia. He joined the human evolution team at the
Wellcome Sanger Institute in 2012 and received his PhD in human
population genetics from University of Cambridge. His doctoral and
postdoctoral work at the Sanger focused on positive selection and
genetic adaptations in humans. He joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2019 and continues to deliver Ensembl training worldwide.

▶️ About the workshop:
This workshop will be divided into two parts. During these two parts you'll learn about:
- Introduction to REST API
- Making requests with R
- Find an endpoint which you can use to lookup information about a gene using its symbol
- Create a URL to find information about a gene
- Expand your results to include information about transcripts
- Convert a fromJSON module used to pull out the data to a dataframe
- Get a sequence in FASTA
- Gene trees and homologues in various formats
- Alignments
- Get all variants that are associated with a phenotype and print the needed information about these variants
- Linking endpoints together
- Using POST to run a query with multiple inputs at once

The invited trainers will go over these materials (http://training.ensembl.org/events/2021/2021-06-04-RLadiesREST_June) during the training session.

By the end of this series, you will be able to make requests with R through Ensembl REST API.

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form 👉
https://tinyurl.com/d7kvxby

We will send you the ZOOM link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Data Visualization: Color Palettes, Themes, and Schemes
description:
For our June event, R-Ladies Anna Sofia Kircher and Joyce Robbins will share short talks about using color palettes, themes, and schemes to improve data visualization in R.

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
7-7:05 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:05-7:30: “ggplot and I” by Anna Sofia Kircher
7:30-7:55: “Does your color palette match your data?” by Joyce Robbins
7:55-8:15: Questions and wrap-up

--- Talk Abstract ---

“ggplot and I”
Speaker: Anna Sofia Kircher

Abstract: This talk will be about how to use ggplot themes and how to personalize them for your purposes. This is motivated by my own obsession with colors and my own experience that different plots with different audiences respond differently to different themes.

Bio: Anna Sofia Kircher is the data scientist at Lendable and works with data of various fintechs in emerging and frontier markets.

“Does your color palette match your data?”
Speaker: Joyce Robbins

Abstract: One of the most common graphical mistakes is choosing an inappropriate color scheme for your data. In this talk, I’ll explain how sequential, diverging and qualitative color schemes are each suited to a different type of data. We’ll then look at a variety of plots that could be improved with alternative color choices. My hope is that these examples will serve as conversation starters for a lively discussion on matching color to data.

Bio: Joyce Robbins (@jtrnyc) is a Lecturer in the Department of Statistics at Columbia University. She specializes in data visualization and statistical literacy.

---

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

For questions regarding accessibility, please email us at nyc@rladies.org.

title: First steps on Git using R-Studio and GitHub
description:
This R-Ladies Tbilisi meetup is happy to welcome Elisa Schneider (see bio below)! During this workshop we will introduce the concept of version control using Git, RStudio and GitHub. We will learn the basic Git commands and how to use them directly from R-Studio. Elisa Schneider will show how to link your R-Projects with GitHub to create online repositories to share your work and how it can be used for collaboration. At the end she will do a short demo on uploading a small WebPage to Github such as the one from R-Ladies Seattle https://github.com/rladies-seattle/rladies-seattle-organizing. If we have enough time she will introduce other possibilities such as GitHub Webpages like this one: https://kyla-mcconnell.github.io/website/index.html.

If you have some time to prepare before the Meetup, Elisa recommends to:
· create a GitHub account (if you do not have one yet) on https://github.com/
· download and install Git from https://git-scm.com/

For the last part of the meetup some very basic knowledge of markdown/Rmarkdown is recommended, but not mandatory, we will also go through it. If you want, you can have a look at the first 35 minutes of this video about RMarkdown: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H91WSwALx1A

Bio
Elisa Schneider comes from Argentina. She studied Biology and also got a degree on Science Education. She specialized in Remote Sensing data analysis and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). She practiced as environmental assessment consultant and also taught cartography and GIS for park rangers. Thanks to a scholarship from the German Academic Exchange Service she was able to complete a master on Environmental Modeling in 2019, at the University of Freiburg. Since then she has been working on the Forest Reaserch Institute of Baden-Württemberg, Germany evaluating forest health from remote sensing data, modeling species distribution and outbreaks of pest insects under climate change. In 2019 she joined R-Ladies Freiburg as a Co-Organizer.

title: R-Ladies Columbus Monthly Meetup
description:
We are at the end of our tidymodels start article saga!
In this session, Ezgi will be back to talking about the tidymodels framework, which is a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles.

We will continue with the 5th get started article on tidymodels.org:
A predictive modeling case study
https://www.tidymodels.org/start/case-study/

We will try fitting two models to predict if hotels guests had accompanied with children or babies with them using lasso and random forest!

If you never worked with tidymodels before or did not attend any of our previous meetups where we covered tidymodels, you can prime yourself with the first four start articles: https://www.tidymodels.org/start/

R-Ladies provides a harassment-free space to all who are interested to share and learn about R!*
___________________________________________________________________________________

We are holding our meetups remotely until further notice.

* R-Ladies Global Code of Conduct: https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: Club de lectura: R para Ciencia de Datos (Wickham & Grolemund)
description:
Las R-Ladies de Barranquilla (COL), Galápagos, Guayaquil y Milagro (ECU) nos hemos unido para traerte un club de lectura basado en el libro R para Ciencia de Datos de Wickham y Grolemund. Este libro está disponible en español gracias a él esfuerzo de la comunidad R latinoamericana y puede ser accedido de manera libre aquí: https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz
En esta tercera sesión de nuestro club de lectura, Isabel Vázquez (R-Ladies Barranquilla) hablara sobre cómo escribir funciones para automatizar flujos de trabajo. Esto incluye el capítulo 19 ( Funciones )
Este club de lectura incluirá varias sesiones quincenales que se llevarán a cabo a través de Zoom. Cada sesión durará dos horas durante las cuales discutiremos y practicaremos los puntos más importantes del capítulo en el que nos enfoquemos para esa sesión. Recuerda, las sesiones son los jueves de cada quincena empiezando a las 18:00(UTC-5, Colombia y Ecuador Continental), o si estás en Galápagos a las 17:00(UTC-6). Al participar en nuestros eventos recuerda que estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta, el cual nos ayuda a crear un espacio amable y seguro para aprender:

https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish

title: Github for collaboration
description:
Details
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new workshop about Using Github for collaboration.

Date/Time: Thursday, June 10th, 2021 from 6 PM to 8 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

▶️ Invited trainer: Dr. Lisa Lendway

▶️ About Dr. Lisa Lendway :
Dr. Lisa Lendway teaches statistics and data science at Macalester College, a small liberal arts college for undergraduates in St. Paul, MN USA. She is passionate about applying statistics to any subject matter and enjoys helping people see the benefits of using statistical analysis and data visualization to answer questions. Outside of statistics, Lisa enjoys spending time with her two daughters, cycling with her husband, making old things new, and playing in her jungle garden. She even went so far as to record her harvest data last year and turn it into an R package: https://github.com/llendway/gardenR

▶️ About the workshop:
In this MeetUp, we'll talk about using Git and GitHub with R projects in the RStudio IDE. This will be a hands-on talk with plenty of opportunity to interact. To get the most out of the meeting, it is recommended that you do a few steps before the meeting: see the "What you should already know" section of my https://lisalendway.netlify.app/posts/2021-02-24-gitinrstudio/ blog post to get your GitHub account set up and to connect it with RStudio. First, we will review how to create our own projects and practice committing, pushing, and creating branches. Then, we will practice adding collaborators where we will clone a repo and deal with a merge conflict. Next, we'll talk about pull requests and practice doing them! Lastly, I'll talk about a couple ways you can undo things you didn't mean to do in Git. I am by no means a Git or GitHub pro. So along the way, I'll probably make some mistakes, but there's no better way to learn, right?

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form 👉
https://tinyurl.com/2k88f8nd

We will send you the zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Filling your bag of workflow tricks
description:
We are super excited to invite you to a new workshop, "Filling your bag of workflow tricks". The amazing Maria Paula Caldas will give an overview of her favourite tricks for working with the RStudio IDE, its addins, and some noteworthy packages that bring joy to her day-to-day coding work.

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R and want to learn how to make your life easier by working in R!
- If you want to learn new tips and improve your skills and learn new tricks for working with the RStudio IDE, its addins.

AGENDA
7:30–7:35 pm Who we are | Announcements
7:35–8:25 pm Filling your bag of workflow tricks
8:25–8:30 pm Any Qs?

Both beginners and experienced R users are welcome to join, and of course, do their little show-and-tell!

Our speaker, María Paula Caldas is a passionate R user, programmer, and certified RStudio Instructor. She has experience using R and Shiny to analyse and communicate data, automate workflows and create reproducible and interactive documents. She currently works as a policy analyst at the OECD, an international organisation based in Paris, France, and previously worked in the private sector as an economics consultant. A social scientist by training, she particularly enjoys teaching R to audiences with diverse academic and cultural backgrounds. In her spare time, she likes to contribute to community-driven projects that increase the visibility of R in non-English speaking regions (e.g. R4DS Spanish translation, rOpenSci Spanish package review). When not in front of a screen, she's probably trying (and failing) to play beginner piano pieces

You can find out more about María Paula Caldas here:

Twitter: https://twitter.com/mapaulacaldas
Website: https://www.mpaulacaldas.com

Place: Zoom- https://zoom.us/download - The event will not be recorded.

We will send you the Zoom link & the passcode via email a few hours before the meetup. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact us :

#LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/r-ladies-saudi-arabia-dammam/
#Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-dammam/
#Twitter: https://twitter.com/RLadiesDammam

title: RLadies Boulder Meetup #15: From csv to slippy map - intro to spatial data in R
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's virtual R Ladies Meetup! This month, Anna Spiers will be giving us an introduction to spatial data and map-making in R!

From Anna: Working with spatial data can feel as finicky as caring for your favorite houseplant - your attempts to help are rejected despite following instructions, and you look longingly at friends' and colleagues' masterpieces (i.e., maps/plants). This talk will introduce spatial data broadly, and cover some of the basic workflows and troubleshooting steps in R. Specifically, we will work with vector data, focus on the `sp` and `sf` libraries, and produce an interactive map in R. Example data and code will be provided.

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

title: Modelli predittivi per la crescita profittevole: il caso Bene Assicurazioni
description:
In questo evento siamo lieti di ospitare un workshop pratico di Bene Assicurazioni, che condividerà con noi come stanno risolvendo le loro sfide quotidiane utilizzando R & big data.

Bene Assicurazioni è una realtà in crescita dalla struttura agile, con molteplici partnership e un modello di business in omni-canalità. La Compagnia ha completato la digitalizzazione dei processi e crede nel continuo aggiornamento delle tecnologie adottate.

Il team BI&A è un gruppo in crescita e con una posizione centrale nella compagnia; è un gruppo giovane, dinamico che si occupa:

Della diffusione della “cultura dei numeri” all’interno della Compagnia
Del governo integrato della reportistica, degli indicatori di performance e di marginalità tecnica
Delle analisi predittive, tecniche e attuariali per ottimizzare il pricing competitivo, la retention e lo sviluppo di nuovi prodotti
Dato il piano di crescita della compagnia, molto ambizioso nel breve-medio termine e da effettuarsi senza intaccare la marginalità, abbiamo studiato con diversi modelli predittivi come modificare il prodotto e il pricing per ottimizzare le nostra crescita, ottenendo infine risultati in linea con le aspettative (Machine Learning works!).

In questo workshop presentiamo il problema ed entriamo nei dettagli di alcuni dei modelli, dei test effettuati e del codice utilizzato per raggiungere il nostro obiettivo.

L'evento sarà in Italiano e sarà trasmesso in streaming tramite Zoom (Non è necessario installare zoom).
Il materiale per il workshop sarà condiviso prima dell'evento.

AGENDA
- Chi siamo – Bene Assicurazioni e il Team BI&A
- Perché abbiamo utilizzato modelli predittivi per stimare la conversion e che risultati abbiamo ottenuto
- Descrizione dei principali algoritmi utilizzati per il modello di conversion e che criteri abbiamo utilizzato per la selezione
- Walk-through di un codice di esempio

Speakers:
+Alessandra Guazzi: Responsabile BI&A e Direct Product Manager;Laureata in Matematica, con un'esperienza di dottorato di ricerca, lavora in Allianz SE come Data Analyst e partecipa all'avvio di un team dedicato all'ottimizzazione dei prezzi per Allianz Australia (Direct). Dopo un'incursione in campo biomedico, lavora come manager in pricing & analytics presso Willis Towers Watson e nel gruppo Cerved.
+Alessandra Villa: Senior Pricing Expert; Laureata in Scienze Statistiche ed Economiche, lavora come attuario presso Zurich Connect per 4 anni, per poi passare a un'esperienza come Pricing Developer in AM Trust. È in Bene Assicurazioni da 2 anni, coordinando le attività di Pricing e Reportistica degli andamenti tecnici.
+Giulia Del Monaco: Data Analyst: Laureata in Biostatistica, inizia a lavorare in Bene nel 2020, dopo 2 esperienze in consulenza (Telematics e Pharma) come data analyst. Ha ottenuto il master in Big Data & Business Analytics del Sole 240re, dove ha supportato il docente con attività di tutoring. Si occupa principalmente di automazione e modelli predittivi in R.
+Simone Cavenago: BI Analyst; Laureato in Scienze Statistiche ed Economiche, inizia a lavorare per Bene Assicurazioni nel 2018. Come principale responsabilità, segue la preparazione ed analisi dei dati e mantiene e sviluppa sulla piattaforma di Business Intelligence (bReport), tutta la reportistica direzionale e dedicata alle agenzie.

Non vedo l'ora di incontrarvi!

title: From messy data to beautiful plot: Guided TidyTuesday
description:
Know the basics of data wrangling but want some hands-on practice? Want to learn ggplot tips and tricks to make your plots eye-catching? Seen cool visualizations on Twitter but find it hard to go from messy dataset to beautiful visualization?

In this monthly meetup, we’ll go through a Tidy Tuesday dataset together step-by-step, walking you through the entire process from coming up with an interesting question to asnwer, getting the data in the right format and finally, creating a cool visualization!

You may have heard of Tidy Tuesday -- a weekly initiative by R for Data Science which provides a new dataset every week for the community to practice wrangling and visualizing. It has a huge Twitter community and is one of the best ways to practice and develop tidyverse skills, whether you’re still reviewing the basics or have quite the repertoire. This series has something for everyone and is especially designed to be beginner friendly!

It's important to us to ensure that Guided Tidy Tuesday is a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. Studies have shown that letting gender minorities speak first promotes a welcoming and supportive atmosphere for underrepresented groups. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: Relatórios e Apresentações em RMarkdown
description:
Quer aprender mais sobre R Markdown? Então não perca o nosso próximo curso online: Relatórios e Apresentações em RMarkdown.

🕓08 e 09/06 de 14h às 16h

✍ ️Inscrições: envie seu nome completo para rladieslavras@gmail.com e aguarde a resposta com a confirmação. A inscrição será efetivada caso existam vagas disponíveis.

💻Vagas disponíveis: 50 (por ser um evento gratuito e com vagas limitadas, só faça a inscrição se você realmente for participar de todas as atividades)

🧭Onde? google meet, o link será enviado aos inscritos antes do início das atividades

Descrição: O RMarkdown é um pacote da linguagem de programação R para criação de documentos dinâmicos. Os documentos R Markdown são escritos em formato de texto de fácil escrita (markdown) e que permite adicionar códigos em R. Neste curso, vamos aprender a criar e modificar cada elemento (código, o texto e o preâmbulo) de um arquivo R Markdown.

Prelecionista: Prof. Elizabeth Mie Hashimoto (UTFPR)

title: Bookclub - Chapter 7: Exploratory Data Analysis Part II
description:
R-Ladies Tbilisi bookclub is continuing its meetings on Hadley Wickham's and Garret Grolemund's "R for Data Science" (https://r4ds.had.co.nz/).

On June 6, Tamar Gogebashvili will present the book's Chapter 7 on exploratory data analysis, starting from sub-chapter 7.5: https://r4ds.had.co.nz/exploratory-data-analysis.html

title: R4Bioinfo Workshop: Introduction to Ensembl REST API - PART1
description:
We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a series of two workshops about Introduction to Ensembl REST API.

Date/Time: Friday, June 4th, 2021 from 6 PM to 8:15 PM (GMT+1)
Place: ZOOM

▶️ Invited trainer: Dr. Aleena Mushtaq and Dr. Michal Szpak

▶️ About Dr. Aleena Mushtaq:
Aleena’s background is in Biomedical and Molecular sciences. She completed her PhD in 2020 at the University of East Anglia, UK. For her doctorate she studied the dynamic relationship of host and microbiota in the gut-liver axis in response to Western diets. She joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2021 and delivers training on Ensembl resources.

▶️ About Dr. Michal Szpak:
Michal took a degree in biology at the University of Warsaw, where he
studied ancient DNA. He subsequently moved to bioinformatics and
explored human genetic variation across different ethnicities in his
master’s degree research at the Center for Public Health Genomics,
university of Virginia. He joined the human evolution team at the
Wellcome Sanger Institute in 2012 and received his PhD in human
population genetics from University of Cambridge. His doctoral and
postdoctoral work at the Sanger focused on positive selection and
genetic adaptations in humans. He joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2019 and continues to deliver Ensembl training worldwide.

▶️ About the workshop:
This workshop will be divided into two parts. During these two parts you'll learn about:
- Introduction to REST API
- Making requests with R
- Find an endpoint which you can use to lookup information about a gene using its symbol
- Create a URL to find information about a gene
- Expand your results to include information about transcripts
- Convert a fromJSON module used to pull out the data to a dataframe
- Get a sequence in FASTA
- Gene trees and homologues in various formats
- Alignments
- Get all variants that are associated with a phenotype and print the needed information about these variants
- Linking endpoints together
- Using POST to run a query with multiple inputs at once

▶️ Requirements of the workshop:
The Ensembl REST API workshop requires familiarity with the Ensembl Browser and data structure. You can find an online version of the Ensembl Browser workshop with exercises here (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/training/online/courses/ensembl-browser-series/). The invited trainers will go over these materials (http://training.ensembl.org/events/2021/2021-06-04-RLadiesREST_June) during the training session.

By the end of this series, you will be able to make requests with R through Ensembl REST API.

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form 👉
https://tinyurl.com/judj2az8

We will send you the ZOOM link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Panel Discussion: What Are Hiring Managers Looking For in Candidates?
description:
DataPhilly, RLadiesPhilly, and the DataLab meetup groups jointly present a panel discussion with hiring managers in the fields of Data Science and Data Engineering!!

The job market for data related jobs is hot. But, job seekers usually find disparity between what recruiters say to what hiring managers really want. We hope to close this disconnect through this discussion and to help candidates better prepare for careers in data engineering or data science and to also help employers find better candidates.

Whether you are looking for a new job in data or are simply interested in what the hiring process looks like, come and ask questions to our panel of eight hiring managers. Stick around after the Q&A and meet these managers face-to-face.

Event Schedule:
1. Meeting opens at 5:45pm
2. Introductions (Starts at 6pm)
3. Panel Q&A (75 minutes)
Moderated discussion on hiring practices and expected skills and experience.
4. Meet the Hiring Managers (30 minutes)
Each hiring manager will have a separate room to meet interested candidates.

Panelists:
Oodaye Shukla - Chief Data Analytics Officer, Eversana
Jason Rodriguez - Data Science Manager, GoPuff
Ryan Harrington - Lead Data Scientist, CompassRed
Johanna-Laina Fischer - Senior Data Scientist, Comcast EBI
Anjali Bansal - Advanced Analytics Lead, Slalom
Dave O’ Toole - Vice President of Analytics, Consumer Behavior, and BI, Revzilla (Comoto Holdings)
Robert Cheetham - CEO, Azavea
Steve Ross - Sr. Manager Security Data Engineering, Elastic

You must download and install Zoom if you have not done it already. Once you have installed Zoom, click on the event link provided in your email to join the meeting.

DON'T FORGET TO ADD YOUR QUESTION TO THE PANEL AFTER YOU RSVP!

title: Club de lectura del libro "Data Feminism" (sesión 1)
description:
¡Hola!

Este jueves 3 de junio nos reuniremos para nuestra primera sesión del club de lectura del libro "Data Feminism", de Catherine D'Ignazio y Lauren F. Klein. Este libro muestra una nueva forma de abordar la ciencia de datos y la ética de datos basada en ideas del feminismo interseccional. Se puede acceder de forma gratuita en: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

¿Cómo funciona el club de lectura?
Dividiremos la lectura del libro en seis sesiones. En cada una de ellas abordaremos un capítulo del libro. Cada sesión la liderará alguien de nuestra comunidad.

Esta primera sesión estará a cargo de Natalia Riquelme (@NatyRiquelmeS), Administradora Pública, estudiante de Magíster en Estadística y Coordinadora de proyectos del Centro de Estudios de Conflicto y Cohesión Social. Durante la sesión comentaremos el capítulo 1, "The Power Chapter", en el que se se presenta el primer principio del feminismo de datos: examinar el poder.

- ¿Qué pasa si no leo en inglés?
¡Puedes participar igual! La persona encargada de cada sesión hará una síntesis de los puntos más importantes, así que incluso si no puedes revisar el libro, podrás aprender sobre este tema :)

- CÓDIGO DE CONDUCTA
Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
El evento se realizará a través de la plataforma Zoom. El día del taller compartiremos la contraseña en los comentarios del evento.

¡Nos vemos!

R-Ladies Talca

title: "Latent Profile Analyses using tidyLPA" with Danica Slavish
description:
For the June 1st edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Dr. Danica Slavish as our guest speaker. Dr. Slavish will introduce the topic of Latent Profile Analyses using the tidyLPA framework.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Latent Profile Analyses using tidyLPA
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: Do adolescents who try alcohol before age 15 have worse health in adulthood than those who try alcohol later in life? Are there different subtypes of COVID-19 symptoms? How do these subtypes predict hospitalization risk? What types of advertisements most strongly predict if someone buys a product?

All these questions can be answered using the statistical technique, latent profile analysis (LPA). LPA is a powerful statistical tool to identify hidden clusters in your data based on a set of variables. LPA is superior to other data reduction techniques like k-means clustering in that it generates probabilities of group membership. In this talk, a brief introduction to LPA using the R package tidyLPA will be covered. Using sample data on daily sleep patterns of nurses, we will walk through an example using the current gold standard 3-step approach: 1) estimate class membership, 2) extract class probabilities, 3) examine predictors of class membership. Best practices and advantages and disadvantages of LPA will be discussed.

Bio: Dr. Danica Slavish is an Assistant Professor of Psychology at the University of North Texas. Danica’s research focuses on how sleep problems and stressful life experiences interact to predict health outcomes across time. Her research team uses a variety of statistical techniques for analyzing longitudinal data in R, including multilevel modeling, time-varying effect modeling, network analyses, and Bayesian analyses. Danica currently teaches courses in health psychology, advanced statistics, and research methods. Before joining UNT, Danica completed her Ph.D. in biobehavioral health at Penn State, where she was a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellow. She holds an undergraduate degree in psychology from Beloit College, in Beloit, WI.

Twitter: https://twitter.com/danicaslavish

Website:

*************************************************************************

You are encouraged to click the link below to keep up with the group project and to join the Slack community. Slack is a messaging platform where we will share open job opportunities, free or low-cost online training materials, and R-Ladies group projects that will help you practice your R programming skills and develop a portfolio that could be used to showcase your skills to hiring managers.

Slack sign-up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdJhvSg-YrNYOrmju1yrXvYhFM7xMey1WpDq1NSGIp6x41VaA/viewform

*************************************************************************

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: Getting Started in R: A Beginner's Guide
description:
Are you new to R? This is the workshop for you!

This workshop is for anyone who is interested in learning R, but doesn’t know where to start! With new folks joining throughout the year, we feel it is important to hold a session for our beginner level members, in order to help establish a strong foundation of skills in R. In this introductory session, we will be going over the basics: how to navigate the different file types, expressions, commands, operators, objects, loops, and MORE!

This session will be led by co-organizer, Cassidy Da Silva (she/her). Cassidy completed her Honours Bachelor’s degree in Biology with an Interdisciplinary Minor in Archaeology at McMaster University in 2019. She is now completing her master’s degree in the Hallgrimsson lab at the University of Calgary, studying the genetics underlying sex differences in human facial morphology. Her primary research interests include morphology, human anatomy, complex trait genetics, and human evolution.

title: Bayesian statistics
description:
Federica Giardina is a public health researcher currently working as an assistant professor in Biostatistics at Radboud University Medical Center (Radboud UMC) in Nijmegen (the Netherlands). She uses Bayesian methods to answer questions in infectious disease epidemiology. Bayesian statistics allows the user to specify prior information to the chosen model. This method is useful, for example, when working with datasets with partially missing data, as is often the case in public health records.

Federica will introduce the Stan programming language (https://mc-stan.org/) with examples of modeling performed with the rstan package.

It's a short introduction, a sweet taste if you like, of a very broad topic that we have been anxious to learn about. Please join us!

title: A quick flight to the edge of the tidyverse
description:
We are very excited to come together with you to host another online meetup. We are collaborating with R-Ladies Tunis to host the second part of the exceptional online session that introduces codes and R functions using cute, fuzzy creatures by the amazing Allison Horst.

The workshop " Explore tidyverse with the funny MonsteRs - part 2" by Allison Horst will help you to picture the functions in your code as cute, fuzzy monsters, and your data as colorful gems. This workshop will make it easier than ever to understand complicated functions in R and create awesome plots.

Our speaker, Allison Horst is an Assistant Teaching Professor at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management, UC Santa Barbara, where she teaches environmental data science, statistics, math, and presentation skills courses. She is also the co-founder of R-Ladies Santa Barbara, founder, and organizer of the UCSB TidyTuesday coding club, and was RStudio's first Artist-in-Residence from 2019 - 2020. Her academic background is in engineering (BS Chemical Engineering, MS Mechanical Engineering) and environmental science (PhD Environmental Science and Management). When she isn't coding or drawing, she enjoys hiking and fly-fishing with her partner Greg and their dog Teddy.

You can find out more about Allison Horst here: https://allisonhorst.github.io/
https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations

Date/Time : Saturday, May 29th, 2021 5PM - 6PM (Tunisia time GMT+1)
Place: Zoom https://zoom.us/download

We will send you the Zoom link and the enter passcode a few hours before the meetup. Please check out your email later.

The same meetup is advertised in both R-Ladies Saudi Arabia (Dammam) and R-ladies Tunis meetup pages (https://www.meetup.com/rladies-tunis/). Please make sure to register only to either of them.

Don't forget to add the event to your calendar so that you get a reminder about it.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Simulación de tiempos de espera en cola usando herramientas de tidyverse
description:
¡Nuevo meetup! y estamos muy emocionadas :D de contar con una destacada R-Lady y científica de datos.

Ana Paula es egresada de Estadística Informática de la UNALM. Actualmente trabaja como Fellow Data Scientist en Mckinsey & Company. Cuenta con 5 años de experiencia construyendo y liderando soluciones analíticas en distintos rubros como banca, telecomunicaciones, construcción, pintura, minería y otros.

• Lo que aprenderemos:
A través de un taller práctico, veremos cómo resolver una problemática de alocación de recursos para reducir tiempos de espera en cola en agencias. Aplicando los paquetes de "tidyverse", veremos su gran utilidad para realizar los análisis de datos y simulaciones necesarios.

• Requisitos:
Asegúrate de tener instalado Zoom.

***IMPORTANTE***
Para participar, dale "Asistiré" en este evento.
Por razones de seguridad no compartiremos el link para ingresar a Zoom de manera pública. Estaremos enviando un correo con el link de zoom.

• Pregunta frecuente:
P: ¿Los chicos son bienvenidos a las reuniones de R-Ladies Lima?
R: Sí, los chicos son bienvenidos a cualquiera de nuestros eventos. Puedes revisar nuestro código de conducta global aquí: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: Regressão com Tidymodels
description:
Heey, tudo bem?

Estamos muito felizes com a sua participação.

Aproveite o curso. Aproveite essa oportunidade! Este evento foi pensado com muito carinho para você.

O que você vai aprender?

Você aprenderá a diferença entre modelos de regressão e classificação e como utilizá-los com o framework Tidymodels. Será mostrado desde a preparação dos dados até a calibração e comparação de modelos através da aplicação prática.

Quais pacotes vão ser utilizados ?

library(tidyverse)
library(tidymodels)

Sobre o Projeto Enigma

O projeto Enigma busca tornar visível o papel feminino na área da computação, resgatando as contribuições significativas de algumas mulheres de uma forma diferenciada, que provoque o pensamento do fruidor. Não pretende-se reproduzir as visibilidades que estas personagens já têm, mas fazer uma provocação, desacomodando o pensamento para que as invisibilidades, que ainda persistem, se tornem visíveis. As doações serão voltadas a reforma de artigos doados ao projeto como computadores, teclados e entre outros objetos do universo computacional.

Para saber mais sobre este projeto lindo acesse https://www.ufrgs.br/enigma/

E aí? Topa?

Link de inscrição: https://www.sympla.com.br/produtor/cursosonline

Dúvidas frequentes:

CERTIFICADOS! - O certificado de 4h do evento será enviado para o seu e-mail. Caso você não receba ao final do evento, escreva para goiania@rladies.org.

MATERIAIS! - Os materiais utilizados no nosso curso (apresentação, scripts) serão disponibilizados através do nosso GitHub .

Dicas importantes para melhor aproveitamento do evento

(1°) Procure conectar o seu computador no cabo de rede, evitando instabilidades na transmissão;
(2°) Pré-configure a sua câmera e microfone antes de entrar no evento pois será útil para as interações com a professora em caso de dúvidas!
(3°) Prepare seu ambiente, aquela caneca de café, garrafa de água e os fones de ouvido, melhores companheiros para se concentrar e mergulhar de cabeça nessa experiência!
(4°) Não guarde esse conhecimento apenas para você, compartilhe com seus amigos e redes sociais marcando a gente no instagram @rladiesgyn.

Você faz parte desse compromisso

Lembre-se que o Código de Conduta também se estende à versão online de nossos eventos e não será tolerada qualquer forma de assédios ou intimidações de qualquer participante, seja audiência, palestrantes, colaboradores, ou quaisquer membros da comunidade.

A gente brilha TOGETHER!

title: Books In Bars - Lessons from Plants
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Lessons from Plants (https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/lessons-from-plants-beronda-l-montgomery/1137725290).

An exploration of how plant behavior and adaptation offer valuable insights for human thriving.

We know that plants are important. They maintain the atmosphere by absorbing carbon dioxide and producing oxygen. They nourish other living organisms and supply psychological benefits to humans as well, improving our moods and beautifying the landscape around us. But plants don’t just passively provide. They also take action.

Beronda L. Montgomery explores the vigorous, creative lives of organisms often treated as static and predictable. In fact, plants are masters of adaptation. They “know” what and who they are, and they use this knowledge to make a way in the world. Plants experience a kind of sensation that does not require eyes or ears. They distinguish kin, friend, and foe, and they are able to respond to ecological competition despite lacking the capacity of fight-or-flight. Plants are even capable of transformative behaviors that allow them to maximize their chances of survival in a dynamic and sometimes unfriendly environment.

Lessons from Plants enters into the depth of botanic experience and shows how we might improve human society by better appreciating not just what plants give us but also how they achieve their own purposes. What would it mean to learn from these organisms, to become more aware of our environments and to adapt to our own worlds by calling on perception and awareness? Montgomery’s meditative study puts before us a question with the power to reframe the way we live: What would a plant do?

title: ggplot2 workshop with Ursula Laa
description:
We are happy to announce that for the May 2021 Meetup our co-organiser Ursula Laa will offer a tutorial into data visualisation with the ggplot2 R package.

Starting from the underlying principles of tidy data and the grammar of graphics, Ursula will introduce the basic ingredients (aesthetics and geoms) and show how to build a ggplot layer-by-layer. We will see together how we can quickly generate very different graphs with small changes in a standard interface, making it easy to better explore data.

Ursula is a researcher in the Statistics Institute of the University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences (BOKU) in Vienna and holds PhD in theoretical particle physics. She focuses in her research on new methods and applications in data science with emphasis on interdisciplinary work, for example connecting her background in physics and her interest in statistical data visualisation.

See you soon online!
Your R-Ladies Vienna Organizing Team

title: Club de lectura Advanced R: Funcionales
description:
¡Ya vamos en el capítulo 9 del libro de Advanced R!

En esta sesión veremos el capítulo 9: Funcionales

https://adv-r.hadley.nz/functionals.html

En este capítulo se muestra cómo reemplazar ciclos for con funcionales, que son funciones que reciben como argumento otra función (como lapply). En particular, el capítulo se enfoca en los funcionales que introduce el paquete purrr.

Será a las 18:00 hora del Centro de la Ciudad de México.

¡No faltes!

title: Club de lectura: R para Ciencia de Datos (Wickham & Grolemund)
description:
Las R-Ladies de Barranquilla (COL), Galápagos, Guayaquil y Milagro (ECU) nos hemos unido para traerte un club de lectura basado en el libro R para Ciencia de Datos de Wickham y Grolemund. Este libro está disponible en español gracias a él esfuerzo de la comunidad R latinoamericana y puede ser accedido de manera libre aquí: https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz
En esta segunda sesión de nuestro club de lectura, Denisse (R-Ladies Galápagos) hablara sobre cómo trabajar con fechas y horas en R, y también que son los pipes y como utilizarlos. Esto incluye el capítulo 16 ( Fechas y horas ) y el capítulo 18 (Pipes)
Este club de lectura incluirá varias sesiones quincenales que se llevarán a cabo a través de Zoom. Cada sesión durará dos horas durante las cuales discutiremos y practicaremos los puntos más importantes del capítulo en el que nos enfoquemos para esa sesión. Recuerda, las sesiones son los jueves de cada quincena empiezando a las 18:00(UTC-5, Colombia y Ecuador Continental), o si estás en Galápagos a las 17:00(UTC-6). Al participar en nuestros eventos recuerda que estás aceptando nuestro código de conducta, el cual nos ayuda a crear un espacio amable y seguro para aprender:

https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish

title: Club de lectura: R para Ciencia de Datos (Wickham & Grolemund) - Sesión 2
description:
Las R-Ladies de Barranquilla (COL), Galápagos, Guayaquil y Milagro (ECU) nos hemos unido para traerte un club de lectura basado en el libro R para Ciencia de Datos de Wickham y Grolemund. Este libro está disponible en español gracias al esfuerzo de la comunidad R latinoamericana y puede ser accedido de manera libre aquí: https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz.

En esta segunda sesión de nuestro club de lectura, Denisse (R-Ladies Galápagos) hablará sobre cómo trabajar con fechas y horas en R, y también qué son los pipes y cómo utilizarlos. Esto incluye al capítulo 16 (Fechas y horas) y el capítulo 18 (Pipes).

Este club de lectura incluirá varias sesiones quincenales que se llevarán a cabo a través de Zoom. Cada sesión durará dos horas durante las cuales discutiremos y practicaremos los puntos más importantes del capítulo o capítulos en el que nos enfoquemos para esa sesión.

Recuerda, las sesiones son los jueves de cada quincena empezando a las 18:00 (UTC-5, Colombia y Ecuador Continental), o si estás en Galápagos a las 17:00 (UTC-6).

title: Introduce yourself online with blogdown & Hugo Apéro
description:
Dragi svi,
jos jedna super radionica sjajne Alison Hill je zakazana za 26. maj i organizuju je divne R-Ladies Tunis. Svi detalji su ovde:

We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new workshop about Using blogdown & Hugo Apéro to create your personal website.

Date/Time: Wednesday, May 26th, 2021 from 7 PM to 9 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

▶️ Invited trainer: Dr. Alison Hill

▶️ About Dr. Alison Hill :
Alison Hill is a data scientist, behavioral scientist, and an award-winning educator. Currently, Dr. Hill works to make data science communication easier and more delightful using RStudio’s open-source toolchain. Previously, Alison was an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Oregon Health & Science University. Her research focused on health-related applications of Natural Language Processing-based methods, and was funded by the National Institutes of Health, the Oregon Clinical and Translational Research Institute, and Autism Speaks. She has written numerous scientific publications on autism and neurodevelopmental disorders and has presented research at over 25 international conferences. Alison has also taught statistics and data science for over 10 years; most recently, she has led advanced workshops on data science communication and machine learning at rstudio::conf, R / Medicine, and R in Pharma. She is also an international keynote speaker (https://alison.rbind.io/talks), co-developer of the palmerpenguins (https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/), distill (https://rstudio.github.io/distill/), and blogdown (https://pkgs.rstudio.com/blogdown) R packages, and co-author of the book blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown (https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown/).

▶️ About the workshop:
“You should have a website!” You may have heard this one before, or even said it yourself. In this workshop, you’ll learn how to build and customize a website from the comfort of the RStudio IDE with R Markdown. We'll use the blogdown package and the Hugo Apéro theme to build and deploy a personal website. We’ll cover basic website care and feeding like using R Markdown to create content, how to use GitHub for version control and Netlify for publishing, and how to use the latest upgrades to the blogdown R package to keep your site up and running.

▶️ Prerequisites

You'll get the most out of this workshop if you do the pre-work ahead of time. Please follow the instructions here: https://iyo-rstudio-global.netlify.app/collection/prework/.

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form 👉 https://tinyurl.com/dre27d3k

We will send you the zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: We R Ladies - Previsão de Séries Temporais com o {fable}
description:
Previsão de Séries Temporais com o {fable}

ESTE EVENTO ACONTECERÁ PELA PLATAFORMA SYMPLA STREAMING!

Link para retirada de ingresso:
https://www.sympla.com.br/produtor/rladiesbh

Quem faz análise de dados sabe: Dados em Séries Temporais são muito recorrentes e tem muita literatura sobre.
Vamos estudar mais técnicas para esse tipo de modelagem? Com uma mulher incrível que sabe do assunto, como sempre!

Conteúdo do Curso:

- O que é um tsibble
- Alguns gráficos de séries temporais com o ggplot2
- Previsões com métodos benchmarks: Mean, naive, snaive e random Walk
- Análise dos Resíduos
- Medidas de Acurácia
- Métodos de Suavização Exponencial
- Modelos Box & Jenkins

Nível de Habilidade: Intermediário

Conheça a facilitadora:

Paula Maçaira - Estatística e Doutora em Engenharia de Produção (https://www.linkedin.com/in/paula-ma%C3%A7aira-97954620b/)

Paula Maçaira é uma entusiasta da programação em R e tem como missão de vida a disseminação desta linguagem nos quatro cantos do Brasil. Formada em Estatística pela ENCE, mestrado em Engenharia Elétrica e doutorado em Engenharia de Produção (PUC-Rio), atua desde 2019 como professora do Departamento de Engenharia Industrial da PUC-Rio. Tem como principais áreas de interesse Estatística Aplicada, Séries Temporais e Forecasting com ênfase no Setor Elétrico e na Saúde. É autora de diversos artigos publicados em periódicos nacionais e internacionais além de atuar como pesquisadora em vários projetos com a indústria.

FAQs:

O que é R?

R é uma linguagem de programação de computador e ambiente de software para computação estatística e gráficos. Confira aqui (https://www.r-project.org/). Ele é usado para análise e visualização de dados em uma ampla variedade de campos.

O que é R-Ladies?

A comunidade R-Ladies é uma organização global que promove a diversidade de gênero na comunidade da linguagem computacional estatística (R). Embora nossos eventos considerem pelo menos o interesse de nível básico em R (algum conhecimento anterior é útil, mas não obrigatório), você é mais que bem-vinde a participar de qualquer uma de nossas sessões para ver o que fazemos.

Onde posso acessar seus materiais?

Vamos carregar os materiais para a nossa pasta no GDrive (https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1UNO_46lSQ63aU71tIR70-7le0ez10HT5).

Eu conheço pouco ou nada sobre a linguagem R, ainda assim posso participar?

Sugerimos pelo menos nível intermediário para o maior aproveitamento do conteúdo.

Preciso de alguma estrutura pra acompanhar o curso?

Para acompanhar o curso online, o ideal é ter acesso a um computador e internet rápida. Uma conta ativa no RStudio Cloud também será necessária. Veja como criá-la aqui: https://medium.com/rladiesbh/r-studio-cloud-como-programar-em-r-usando-a-web-aa6313a5fb8c E aproveita e deixa seu like!

Vai ter certificado?

Sim, todo mundo que comparecer ao evento terá direito a um certificado de 1h30.

O curso é gratuito?

Teremos um número limitado de vagas gratuitas. As demais serão contribuições para o Projeto Animal.

Eu sou homem, posso me inscrever?

Este grupo é principalmente voltado para o público feminino e LGBTQIA+, mas está aberto a todos que concordam com o Código de Conduta (https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/). Dito isto, se você é um homem e quer participar dos nossos encontros, você está convidado a participar!

Ficou alguma dúvida?

É só enviar para belohorizonte@rladies.org ;)

title: Exploring Our Universe Through Sight & Sound (or Touch!)
description:
Information of cosmic objects doesn't have to be just a two-dimensional snap shot. We can transform these data to be able to listen, feel, or (virtually) move through the cosmos through virtual reality and even holograms. Such data taken from telescopes in space – often in light invisible to the human eye – can be translated into many different forms to help provide access to some of space’s most interesting and mysterious objects. Dr. Kimberly Arcand, from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory, will take you to the debris from an exploded star through sound, walk you through the core of our Milky Way virtually, discuss feeling vibrations of a stellar nursery, and help you experience our universe anew.

For information about our speaker, Kimberly Arcand, please go to https://www.kimarcand.com/about.

title: ¡Primer meet-up R-Ladies Guayaquil!
description:
¡Comienza la iniciativa en la ciudad! ¡Bienvenid@s!
En esta primera reunión nos conoceremos y te diremos qué trae consigo esta maravillosa iniciativa. ¿Las mujeres participan en ciencias? ¿matemáticas? ¿tecnologías?, no sólo contestaremos estas preguntas; también explicaremos qué es R y cómo su uso es transversal en distintas áreas de aplicación.
Recuerda que todos los eventos son gratuitos.

¡Anímate a estar 15 minutos antes de la hora de inicio para el registro!

¡L@s esperamos!

title: Common Statistical Tests in R (t-tests, linear regression, ANOVA)
description:
By the end of this event, participants will be able to perform one- and two-sample t-tests, linear regression, and ANOVA. We will discuss how to understand the output and look at diagnostics of the tests. We will not focus on data cleaning and data for examples will already be in ideal format. If time allows, we will discuss logistic regression.

Agenda:
• 6:30 pm - 6:45pm - Introductions
• 6:45 pm - 8:15 pm - Examples and practice
• 8:15 pm - 8:30 pm - Wrap up

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

Who is this for?
This meetup is for beginners who have little to no experience programming in R. We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

**Before you join**, please install the most recent version of R **as well as** RStudio on your computer before attending this meetup event. Here are links to free downloads for R (https://cran.r-project.org/) and RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download). Downloading and installing both of these programs before this meetup will help us keep to our schedule and make sure you learn the most you can while at the meetup event.

If you have trouble installing the software, please contact Stephanie at least 48 hours **before the event** so we can find a time to meet and work through software installation issues.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R **and** RStudio. See information above about how to install R **and** RStudio.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

title: A Gentle Introduction to Parallel Processing in R with Danielle Ferraro
description:
PLEASE NOTE: This event has been rescheduled for Wednesday, May 26th from 5:30-7:00pm PT.

Ready to learn how to write faster code? In this workshop, Danielle will provide an overview on parallel processing - that is, how to take advantage of your computer’s multicore processor to complete large tasks more quickly. We will cover what parallel processing is, when to use it, and review some packages and code to get started with parallelization in R.

If folks want to code along with Danielle they can clone or download the repo here:
https://github.com/danielleferraro/rladies-sb-parallel

Necessary packages include:
- foreach
- doParallel
- furr
- future.apply
- dplyr
- tictoc

If you have any questions before then feel free to reach out to Juliette, Sam, or An!

title: Social Vulnerability and COVID-19 Prevalence & Predicting Benzodiazepines Use
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, May 18, 6:30-8:00 pm (Pacific)
6:30 - Welcome and Networking
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - Social vulnerability and COVID-19 prevalence in California
7:25 - Q&A
7:30 - Predicting Benzodiazepines Use
7:55 - Q&A
8:00 - Meeting Adjourned

# Social Vulnerability and COVID-19 Prevalence in California
Speakers: Tiffany Feng, Eustina Kim, Diana Pham, Kienna Qin
Seniors, Department of Statistics, UCLA

Bio: Tiffany Feng, UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Digital Humanities minor; Eustina Kim: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Digital Humanities minor; Diana Pham: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Global Health minor; Kienna Qin: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major

Abstract:
The goal of this project was to determine if there is a relationship between social vulnerability and COVID-19 case prevalence rates across counties in California. Social vulnerability is defined as the resilience of communities when dealing with external stresses on health, such as age, housing, race/ethnicity, and more. For analysis, we used multiple linear regression to determine which social vulnerability variables are most directly related with hospital capacity in each county in California, using average bed utilization rate as our measure of hospital capacity. The significant predictors from our model were: the proportion of the county’s population under 17, the percentage of individuals reporting severe housing situations, the proportion of the county's population that are Black, the percentage of single parent households, and the percentage of households with more people than rooms. We then developed a county-level social vulnerability index (SVI) and concluded that there was a relationship between the SVI and COVID-19 case prevalence per county after mapping both of them using Tableau. Our findings suggest that more socially vulnerable counties are less equipped to handle impacts of COVID-19 and more resources should be allocated to them to establish equitable health outcomes. This project was originally created in May 2020, with updates to COVID case rates in December 2020.

# Predicting Benzodiazepines Use
Speakers: Tiffany Feng, Eustina Kim, Diana Pham, Kienna Qin
Seniors, Department of Statistics, UCLA

Bio: Tiffany Feng, UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Digital Humanities minor; Eustina Kim: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Digital Humanities minor; Diana Pham: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Global Health minor; Kienna Qin: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major

Abstract: This project explores which characteristics among students, health care professionals, and veterans determined the use of benzodiazepines (BZDs) in a sample of participants in the United States during 2018. BZDs are a type of drug that produces sedation and lowers anxiety levels. They are the most commonly prescribed medication in the U.S., and, unfortunately, are frequently abused and taken with other drugs. We used multinomial logistic regression and various data visualizations to determine that having a history of drug use, mental illness, and prescriptions for opioids for treating pain are important in predicting the use of BZD for all three occupations in our sample. The largest impacts for each occupation were a history of drug use for students, mental illness and opioid prescriptions for pain for veterans, and there were similar influences for each category for health professionals. Although our data was not a representative sample, this could still demonstrate the importance of investigating the unique differences in determining BZD use for each occupation, which could lead into interventions such as targeted programs to reduce BZD misuse in each occupation. Hopefully with these insights, we can make a positive impact on the lives of those affected by the misuse of BZDs in the United States.

# Meeting Materials
All meeting materials will be sent to registered attendees after the event.
